item.title: If I remember correctly, thereâ€™s no good solution to run background service for tracking locationâ€¦
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Doh
item.content:encoded: If I remember correctly, thereâ€™s no good solution to run background service for tracking location from devices you mentioned. Just one way to use location is that foreground service, and also you should make a good scenario to provide acceptable reasons about using location to your users. GoodÂ luck.

item.title: I heard and experienced similar cases like you mentioned but not on the Android O.
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Doh
item.content:encoded:
I heard and experienced similar cases like you mentioned but not on the Android O. Nowadays I heard SAMSUNG will drop their own lifecycle monitoring system, instead, theyâ€™ll use one that Google provides. Iâ€™m not sure of whether we have to have a plan B or not at this point, but also Iâ€™m sure itâ€™s strange behavior against theÂ rule.

Thanks for sharing your experiences.Â :)

item.title: Wow, itâ€™s too late to answer.
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Doh
item.content:encoded: Wow, itâ€™s too late to answer.Â :/ I just wanna mention you can write Job or JobIntentService to collect geolocation, and also RN module to provide API that could access those data. But, you should know that thereâ€™re lots of limitations for accessing user location in background. ThanksÂ :)

item.title: Iâ€™m using 1.2.51, and AFAIK there is no any other things you need to set.
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Doh
item.content:encoded: Iâ€™m using 1.2.51, and AFAIK there is no any other things you need toÂ set.

item.title: Thanks for reading my article, Pedro. :)
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Doh
item.content:encoded:
Thanks for reading my article, Pedro.Â :)

â€˜by lazy {}â€™ is still available even at Kotlin 1.2.51 which currently Iâ€™m using. I donâ€™t know why sample code doesnâ€™t work in your case, just wanna mention â€˜.valueâ€™ do getting value from cached result of initialization block and also do initializing if it doesnâ€™t have cached result. So, your code means executing initialization block immediately and then assign the cached result to mTextViewWelcome. At this point property delegation would be dropped likeÂ below:

private val mTextViewWelcome: TextView = 
    findViewById(R.id.message) as TextView

item.title: IMHO, thereâ€™s no more restriction than you may know.
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Doh
item.content:encoded: IMHO, thereâ€™s no more restriction than you may know. Just one thing I wanna mention as my article, JobIntentService doesnâ€™t promise starting itself immediately. I donâ€™t have any experience to implement widgets, but guess widget mostly stay in the truely background in your case. And also it means Job would take some time to be run by system. You may need to wait running your Job on the app which targets Oreo on the Oreo device for aÂ while.

item.title: I was very excited that seeing you working and sharing lots of things about ServiceWorker.
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Doh
item.content:encoded: I was very excited that seeing you working and sharing lots of things about ServiceWorker. I thought you guys have been changing the world. Hope seeing you always standing on the future of Web. Cheers!Â â˜º
